awd_titl_txt: Numerical Solution of Constrained Optimization Problems Governed by Partial Differential Equations with Uncertain Parameters
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will provide new mathematical algorithms and theoretical analyses for the solution of optimization problems governed by partial differential equations (PDEs) with uncertain parameters. These problems arise in many science and engineering decision making applications, where a decision has to be made before the realization of uncertain inputs can be observed that will impact the outcome of the decision. The uncertainty can be incorporated into the optimization formulation using so-called risk measures, which typically involve the expected value of the quantity of interest and a measure of its deviation from the expected value. In principle, these formulations allow one to compute decisions that balance maximization of their expected outcome and minimization of the risk due to uncertainty. However, the numerical solution of these problems presents many theoretical and algorithmic challenges.  For example, the numerical solution requires some sort of sampling of the random inputs, which can make these PDE constrained optimization problems extremely expensive to solve. 

To address several of the above mentioned challenges, this research will provide theoretical analyses of the well-posedness and of optimality conditions for a class of semilinear elliptic PDE constrained optimization problems, and it will derive discretization error bounds for sparse grid and quasi Monte Carlo discretizations applied to PDE constrained optimization. Furthermore, it will develop and analyze adaptive methods which reduce the total number of samples needed, or incorporate reduced order models. This research is at the interface between stochastic programming, deterministic PDE constrained optimization, and solution of PDEs with random inputs, and it will make algorithmic and theoretical contributions to these areas. The application of theories and numerical methods to example problems will serve as a model for other researchers and decision makers, and will lead to more efficient algorithms for important classes of decision making under uncertainty. Results will be disseminated through publication of algorithms and results. In addition, the results of the project will be used in regularly offered courses on the theory and applications of optimization as well as in special courses on PDE constrained optimization under uncertainty aiming at students in both mathematics and engineering.

por.por_cntn:
This project has developed new approaches for the efficient estimation of so-called risk-measures applied to quantities of interest (QoI) that require the solution of partial differential equations (PDEs), and new methods for risk-averse optimization governed by PDEs with uncertain parameters. These tasks arise in many science and engineering problems where one wants to, e.g., assess the performance of a system or maximize the performance of a system when the system is modeled by PDEs and some system parameters (material parameter, environmental conditions such a temperature) are not known completely and are modeled by random variables or random fields. Using the expected value to assess the performance includes no information about the deviation of actual performance from expected performance. In contrast, risk-measures quantify deviation of actual performance from expected performance and are important in applications where under-performance leads to failure. A particular risk-measure is the conditional-value-at-risk (CVaR), which originated in the financial application, but is increasingly used in engineering applications because it measures degree of failure (degree of under-performance).

Computing the risk-measure of a QoI, let alone minimizing the risk-measure of a QoI is challenging because the risk-measure depends only on a small number of events in the tail of the probability distribution function (PDF) of the QoI. Sampling this PDF is expensive, since each sample requires the solution of a PDE. Additionally, many risk-measures introduce non-smoothness.

One outcome of this project is the systematic and efficient integration of reduced-order models (ROMs) into the efficient CVaR estimation of a computationally expensive QoI. Efficiency is gained by replacing computationally expensive full-order model (FOM) simulations by inexpensive ROM simulations. Additional efficiency is achiecved by exploiting the structure of CVaR, which implies that a ROM used for CVaR estimation only needs to be accurate in a small region of the parameter space, called the ε-risk region. Hence, FOM queries needed to improve the ROM can be restricted to this small region of the parameter space, thereby substantially reducing the computational cost of ROM construction. Error bounds for the ROM-based CVaR estimates have been developed and the overall performance gains have been demonstrated on test problems inspired by engineering applications.

Another outcome is new Newton-type methods for CVaR optimization. CVaR and other risk-measures introduce non-smoothness into the objective function in risk-averse optimization. A popular approach to solve these problems is to apply smoothing and then employ Newton methods. In addition to conditioning problems arising from smoothing, in this case Newton-type methods can suffer from rank deficiency in the Hessian of the smoothed CVaR objective, which arises from the fact that the second derivative of the smoothing function is zero outside a small interval. This research has developed a simple modification, which introduces a computationally inexpensive sub-step that utilizes the structure of the smoothed CVaR objective to generate a consistent quadratic model. This modification leads to better Newton-CG steps and substantially reduces the number of Newton-CG iterations. Furthermore, efficient gradient and Hessian-times-vector computations were devised for smoothed CVaR optimization governed by PDE constrains that use the structure of CVaR to drastically reduce the number of adjoint PDE and linearized PDE solves needed during optimization.

Additional outcomes include development of new ROMs for optimization problems with variables initial conditions and new inexact Newton-Kleinman low-rank ADI solution method for standard Riccati equations associated with Hessenberg index-2 Differential Algebraic Equation (DAE) systems. The latter have been successfully applied to Riccati equations that arise in the computation of stabilizing feedback laws for semi-discretized, linearized (around steady state) Navier-Stokes equations.

Optimization problems governed by PDEs with Uncertain Parameters arise in many science and engineering applications. Therefore, the new efficient algorithms developed in this project will increase the number of important problems for which uncertainty can be rigorously incorporated into the solution process. The publications resulting from this research contain careful and detailed descriptions of the algorithms, which will allow others to adopt them in their research or for their applications.

This project has directly supported two graduate students. In addition, the research performed under this project was used as the basis for several lectures or tutorial talks given to many other researchers and graduate students. In addition, the PI has repeatedly given presentations to high school students to highlight the impact of STEM on daily applications.
